items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
The New Street Flood Gate in Upton upon Severn will be opened this afternoon. We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

River levels have risen and remain high at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury including the B3493 near Llansantffraid Bridge. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peak based on forecast rainfall :- Llanymynech 3.8 to 4.1m overnight on Thursday 30/12/21. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 9am on Friday 31/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green between 5.3 and 5.8m on Friday afternoon 31/12/21, Montford 4.7 to 5.2m on Saturday morning 01/01/22, Welshbridge 2.4 to 2.9m on Saturday afternoon, Buildwas 3.5 to 4m overnight on Saturday, Bridgnorth 2.7 to 3.2m Sunday morning 02/01/22.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 9am on Friday 31/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen and remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 on 31/12/21, or if the situation changes

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Milford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   We do not forecast the situation to deteriorate any further.
We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are farmland in the Willington, Ingleby, Barrow on Trent and Swarkestone and Bargate Lane and the access to Willington Meadows at Willington and Twyford Village access road - Church Lane at Barrow and Ingleby Lane may be affected above this level.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 31/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message: River levels have risen and remain high at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. As further rainfall is expected river levels will remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 31/12/2021 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook

items.message:
The risk of flooding from the River Roding has now reduced and levels have fallen below that of concern. 
There may still be some flooding to fields adjacent to the river and standing water could be seen for several days. However, river levels are forecast to continue to drop over the coming days and these areas of water will clear away.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and reissue this flood alert if the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but gradually falling on the lower River Ray following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue today (30/12/21), especially in areas between Lower Arncott and Islip. 
Further rain is forecast this morning, 30/12/21, which should clear by this afternoon. Patchy showers move through the area overnight with the potential to be heavy at times. River levels are steadily falling at Lower Arncott. Levels have now stabilised at Islip but remain very high due to high levels on the River Cherwell. Levels will continue to fall but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated this evening, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Clyst has now reduced and rivers have fallen below levels of concern. River levels are expected to fall slowly throughout today and into the evening. River levels are presently still high and will be sensitive to further rainfall. The heavy rainfall experienced on Wednesday, 29th December has cleared the area and no further heavy rainfall is currently forecast. The Environment Agency will continue to monitor the situation and issue any further updates as necessary

items.message:
The risk of flooding from the Upper River Tamar has now reduced and the river has fallen below the level of concern. There is no longer a threat of flooding. No property flooding is expected. River levels are expected to fall throughout today and into the evening.
The Environment Agency will continue to monitor the situation and issue any further updates as necessary.

items.message: River levels are high at the Beggearn Huish river gauge and are forecast to rise overnight as a result of further rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible for several hours from 04:00 tomorrow morning, 31/12/21. Flooding may affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this time. We expect river levels to begin falling later tomorrow morning on 31/12/21. No significant rainfall is expected for the remainder of Friday, 31/12/21. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 tomorrow, 31/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours and into the weekend, therefore we will closely monitor the situation and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Thame downstream of Aylesbury following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue today, 30/12/21, especially in areas between Thame and Dorchester. 
Further rain is forecast this morning, 30/12/21, which should clear by this afternoon. Patchy showers move through the area overnight with the potential to be heavy at times.  River levels have fallen below the flood risk threshold in the Aylesbury area, but remain high downstream. River levels are high in the Thame area but are gradually falling. Levels continue to rise between Stadhampton and Dorchester. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated this evening, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are falling on the River Wey following recent rainfall. Rainfall this morning should clear in the afternoon, further showers are forecast overnight into tomorrow, 31/12/21.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are slowly falling at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. River levels are slowly falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, Thursday, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. We expect river levels to remain high until 09:00 on 31/12/21. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. We continue to monitor the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the Lower Cherwell following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue, especially in Thrupp and Kidlington areas. 
Further rain is forecast this morning, 30/12/21, which should clear by this afternoon. Patchy showers move through the area overnight with the potential to be heavy at times. Levels remain high but are gradually falling in the Thrupp and Kidlington areas. River levels continue to fall in the Lower Heyford area where they should now be mostly back within banks. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall and will remain high over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated this evening, 30/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels in the Eastern Yar remain high in places but are now falling. Only 2mm of rain has been recorded at Knighton in the last 24 hours and the situation is improving, although out of bank impacts remain. Little rain is expected on Friday 31/12/21, but heavier showers are possible over the Bank Holiday weekend which could see as much as 45mm of rain. This would cause the river levels to rise again, and residents are recommended to keep flood protection products ready. We continue to monitor the forecast and keep the river free of any reported blockages. This Flood Alert will be updated or removed by 12:00 on 1/1/2022.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault river gauge as a result of rainfall earlier this week. We expect flooding to affect The Causeway at Sutton Gault   
This information is correct as of 15:30 on Thursday 30th December. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 18 centimetres of water currently on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
There are currently no issues on the Earith or Welney Causeways. 
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 31/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault river gauge as a result of rainfall earlier this week.  
This information is correct as of 15:30 on Thursday 30th December. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 18 centimetres of water currently on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY.
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 31/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but stable at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from today, 30/12/2021 and into tomorrow 31/12/2021.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
Further patchy but generally light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high but relatively stable for at least the next 48 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated by 20:00 on Thursday, 30/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise as a result of persistent rainfall today (Thursday, 30/12/21), which is expected to continue until tomorrow morning (Friday, 31/12/21). Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 17:00pm tonight (Thursday, 30/12/21) and 12:00 tomorrow (Friday, 31/12/21). Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. We expect river levels to rise until mid-morning on Friday (31/12/21), after which time this band of rain is forecast to clear to the north-east and we expect river levels to drop. Our incident response staff are checking defences and closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Be prepared to act on your flood plan. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Sankey catchment with St Helens and Warrington
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Sankey due to persistent rainfall.
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around Black, Barkers, Windle and Whittle Brooks and their tributaries from this afternoon (30/12/2021). Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon and throughout the evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely and will issue flood warnings if necessary. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning (31/12/2021), or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise as a result of persistent rainfall today (Thursday, 30/12/21), which is expected to continue until tomorrow morning (Friday, 31/12/21). Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 22:00 PM (30/12/21), however flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Areas most at risk are Skipton Washlands, Snaygill Ings, and Cononley Washlands. We expect river levels to rise until mid-morning on Friday (31/12/21), after which time this band of rain is forecast to clear to the north-east and we expect river levels to drop. Our incident response staff are checking defences and closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Be prepared to act on your flood plan. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

River levels will rise steadily on the River Ribble and River Darwen due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include River Ribble from Samlesbury and the River Darwen from Darwen including Blackburn, Preston, Walton-Le-Dale, Pleasington and Higher Walton.
Flooding is possible at River Ribble from Samlesbury and the River Darwen from Darwen including Blackburn, Preston, Walton-Le-Dale, Pleasington and Higher Walton from 05:00 PM on 30/12/2021.
River levels are expected to remain high overnight on 30/12/2021.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 08:00 AM on 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon and throughout the evening. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise overnight on the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck and other watercourses, from Coniston to Barrow-in-Furness including low lying areas around Ulpha, Duddon Bridge, Broughton in Furness, Kirkby-in-Furness, Dalton in Furness and Ulverston. Flooding is possible from 18:00 PM on 30/12/2021.
Further showers are forecast on Friday and throughout the weekend which we will continue to monitor, we are not expecting these to cause further flooding impacts. 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are clearing debris from weed screens in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow, the 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the Bessy Brook due to heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property is possible today, 30/12/2021. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue further flood warnings if necessary. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Fouracres and The Crescent at Maghull
items.message:
River levels are rising steadily on the Whinney Brook and Dovers Brook due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Whinney Brook and Dovers Brook, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties on Fouracres and The Crescent which are at risk from surface water flooding.
Flooding of land and property is possible from 07:00 PM on 30/12/2021.
River levels are expected to remain high overnight.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one
This message will be updated by 08:00 AM on 31/12/2021, or as the situation changes.
